key_points: Citibank mistakenly wired $900 million to Revlon's lenders; only seeking to return $500 million.
A US District Court judge ruled against Citibank recovering the accidentally wired funds.
The incident is considered one of the 'biggest blunders in banking history.'
Under New York law, the 'discharge-for-value-defense' allows beneficiaries to keep money if they are entitled to it and unaware of the mistake.
Revlon's lenders believed Citibank's transfer was a prepayment of the loan.
The court found it 'borderline irrational' to expect the lenders to assume Citibank had made such a mistake.
Internal chats among HPS employees showed they were unaware the transfer was a mistake at first.
Despite the court ruling, a temporary restraining order is in effect pending a possible appeal.
Citibank intends to appeal the decision, believing it is entitled to recover the funds.
The mishap reflects the risks and challenges digital money transfers pose in the modern financial system.
spokespersons: Benjamin Finestone (Representative, Lenders Brigade and HPS Investment Partners)
